author: Kiriakos [SPEC]
title: NFT Guaranteed Storage
description: Cardano (NFT\*) Projects rely on IPFS to store asset data. IPFS does NOT guarantee storage. Most projects are at risk of losing that data.

assessments.note: The proposal addresses the Developer ecosystem challenge and also supports one of the supposed in-demand DApp requests (i.e. NFTs). Having a guaranteed store and showing interoperability between Cardano and Filecoin is a positive.

The deliverable is open-source software that can be used by developers, so this is within the scope of the challenge.
Deduction of one star because it is unclear who is asking for this product.
Interesting project. Competes with "Cardano IPFS chronicles" which already provides a similar service and wants a smaller amount of funds to continue it.

Having an additional layer of back-up would certainly add value to the Cardano ecosystem as a whole. However I fail to see how it addresses the challenge of improving the experience of and creating a more appealing environment for developers on Cardano. Perhaps a future version of this proposal could be placed in a different category or adapted to more specifically address the needs of devs. I understand that devs, too would in a way benefit from improved storage options but it doesn't seem to address their needs specifically.

The proposal attempts to solve a problem associated principally with transfer and ownership of NFTs, not their development. 

The proposal identifies a potential data loss problem for NFTs that maintain off-chain assets on the Interplanetary File System (IPFS). 

The proposer correctly points out that an NFT can suffer data loss if the owner does not "pin" an IPFS object to guarantee its persistence as required by the protocol.

To combat this problem, a software solution is proposed that will migrate IPFS objects referenced in an NFT to the Filecoin network, manage payment and storage parameters for the objects on the Filecoin network,  and act as a host for "robust" retrieval of the objects.

Both the IPFS and Filecoin community have developed products and services, for audiences of varying sophistication, that guarantee storage and delivery of IPFS objects according to a policy such as Lotus, Powergate, Starling, Slate, Pinata, Infura,  etc. The proposal does not explain and it is not apparent how the proposed "in-scope" solution is different from these existing solutions or will materially reduce the cost or complexity of NFT development in additional ways. 

For these reasons, the proposal does not effectively address the challenge of improving the developer ecosystem of Cardano. 

This proposal may benefit from being recategorized and focused to deal with the problems of owners, purchasers, and resellers of NFTs.   A tool that identifies risks or problems with a particular NFTs integrity and potentially offers advice for the mitigation or resolution of these issues may be valuable to a less technical audience.

IPFS is been the preferred storage system for NFT files in Cardano. The proposal is for creating a bridge with filecoin storage, that has an assured storage feature. This is likely to be useful for a few NFT that require such reliable storage requirements.

The idea is good, it addresses a real problem and it is a good application of the blockchain technology. I would suggest that this was created as generally as possible (I believe it will be done like that) to make it easier to migrate to a future solution of decentralized data storage in the Cardano blockchain, and also it would be good to pay attention to the scalability of this solution since it might need to store tons of data. Besides that, I believe it is a very good solution.
The proposer's experience and estimated time and high-level breakdown for completion, as well as definitions of in-scope vs out-of-scope work convey a moderate likelihood of success.

The proposer seems to have studied the problem of decentralised storage in detail and was able to provide adequate answers to all the questions placed by the community in the comments and seems very knowledgeable about the problem he is attempting to solve. Would have like to see more info about the proposers background and links to credentials and previous works and I would suggest including these in future iterations or future proposals.

The proposer does not describe their development experience with the Cardano, IPFS, or Filecoin ecosystems such that a judgment can be made whether or not the project can be completed successfully.

The proposal does not outline the challenges likely to be encountered during development so that the risk of not completing can be assessed.

The plan does not adequately explain why a "naive" implementation is useful to the realization of the "robust" final deliverable.

The plan does not lay out why the "robust" solution is a reasonable or necessary step to achieve the ideal oracle-based solution proposed for later funds.

The ideal oracle-based solution is not described in enough detail that its efficacy or relative worth can be evaluated.

The proposal alludes to the addition of smart contracts in future funds but does not explain how they can improve the solution.

The plan doesn't explain why it is necessary to purchase Fil tokens or how they will be used in the deliverable for this fund.

No discussion of the ongoing NFT standardization efforts is mentioned or accounted for in the plan.

Without an accounting of the direct or indirect experience of the proposer with the protocols in question or a more detailed plan for the evolution of the final solution, the likelihood of successful completion cannot be assesed.
The proposer is operating spectrum pool and has demonstrated expertise in the related field.

The proposer alleged has experience with blockchain and software development, so it might not be difficult to implement this. Since it is going to be an open-source development, also, it's even better to find bugs and improve the code in general. The roadmap and each steps to make it possible are clear, so I don't see man difficulties in implementing this solution.

The proposal almost trivializes the work necessary. It appears that the proposer has a pretty good handle on the situation and conveys enough info for people somewhat familiar with Filecoin and IPFS. A little bit more background on the problem that it's trying to solve would make this proposal stronger.

In the future I would suggest the inclusion of an estimated implementation start date for the project and expected delivery date. The number of hours required, but a clear roadmap isn't given. Those hours could be spend 1/day or 10/day, without a clear roadmap it's hard to judge. Even if the project would be for a one-man coding operation an assessment of risks should have been made. However it would be relatively easy to verify the progress and deployment of a functional MVP.

The proposal has presented two simple and clear aims of creating a centralized bridge followed by a load-balanced revival of file coin object through public IFPS. The progress is clearly auditable, and its utilization will provide a measure of its success. 
The bridge will be open source and every user will be host it to pay for the gas fee in the filecoin network/

The steps of this development are clear, and this could also be considered as milestones of the roadmap. Although, I believe that the proposal needs to include some information about KPIs and key metrics in order to properly measure its success. And also to include some dates related to each step (or deliverable). Some scaling challenges should also be considered, and the cost of transactions between Filecoin and Cardano should be assessed as a possible risk, for examples. Other risks of creating such a bridge should be discussed.

No comprehensive description of the functional or performance characteristics of either the "naive" or "robust" systems is provided such that the proposal could be audited. 

It is not clear how or when this product would be used in the lifecycle of an NFT. The proposal would benefit greatly from a well-defined set of use cases and associated acceptance criteria.

This CA would be particularly interested in how this solution would interact with the broader Cardano DeFi ecosystem and how that could be audited.

solution: Create a bridge from Cardano to Filecoin to ensure storage of tokens.
experience:
Decades of software development experience creating web scale applications and running them.

6+ years of blockchain ops.
